elements.content: Water-stable metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with proton-conducting behavior have attracted great attention as promising materials for proton-exchange membrane fuel cells. Herein, we report the mechanochemical gram-scale synthesis of three new mixed-ligand phosphonate-based MOFs, {Co­(H2PhDPA)­(4,4′-bipy)­(H2O)·2H2O} n (BAM-1), {Fe­(H2PhDPA)­(4,4′-bipy) (H2O)·2H2O} n (BAM-2), and {Cu­(H2PhDPA)­(dpe)2(H2O)2·2H2O} n (BAM-3) [where H2PhDPA = phenylene diphosphonate, 4,4′-bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine, and dpe = 1,2-di­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene]. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements revealed that BAM-1 and BAM-2 are isostructural and possess a three-dimensional (3D) network structure comprising one-dimensional (1D) channels filled with guest water molecules. Instead, BAM-3 displays a 1D network structure extended into a 3D supramolecular structure through hydrogen-bonding and π–π interactions. In all three structures, guest water molecules are interconnected with the uncoordinated acidic hydroxyl groups of the phosphonate moieties and coordinated water molecules by means of extended hydrogen-bonding interactions. BAM-1 and BAM-2 showed a gradual increase in proton conductivity with increasing temperature and reached 4.9 × 10–5 and 4.4 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 90 °C and 98% relative humidity (RH). The highest proton conductivity recorded for BAM-3 was 1.4 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 50 °C and 98% RH. Upon further heating, BAM-3 undergoes dehydration followed by a phase transition to another crystalline form which largely affects its performance. All compounds exhibited a proton hopping (Grotthuss model) mechanism, as suggested by their low activation energy.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements revealed that BAM-1 and BAM-2 are isostructural and possess a three-dimensional (3D) network structure comprising one-dimensional (1D) channels filled with guest water molecules. Instead, BAM-3 displays a 1D network structure extended into a 3D supramolecular structure through hydrogen-bonding and π-π interactions. In all three structures, guest water molecules are interconnected with the uncoordinated acidic hydroxyl groups of the phosphonate moieties and coordinated water molecules by means of extended hydrogen-bonding interactions. BAM-1 and BAM-2 showed a gradual increase in proton conductivity with increasing temperature and reached 4.9 × 10-5 and 4.4 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 90 °C and 98% relative humidity (RH). The highest proton conductivity recorded for BAM-3 was 1.4 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 50 °C and 98% RH. Upon further heating, BAM-3 undergoes dehydration followed by a phase transition to another crystalline form which largely affects its performance. All compounds exhibited a proton hopping (Grotthuss model) mechanism, as suggested by their low activation energy.

elements.content: Three mixed ligand phosphonate-based MOFs, BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3, were synthesized by green mechanochemical synthesis using a small amount of water as solvent. All these MOFs show high proton conduction promoted by extended hydrogen-bonding between guest water molecules, phosphonate moieties, and coordinated water molecules.
elements.clean_text: Three mixed ligand phosphonate-based MOFs, BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3, were synthesized by green mechanochemical synthesis using a small amount of water as solvent. All these MOFs show high proton conduction promoted by extended hydrogen-bonding between guest water molecules, phosphonate moieties, and coordinated water molecules.

elements.content: The consumption of nonrenewable fossil fuels has caused severe environmental damage. Correspondingly, the need for alternative green energy sources is more urgent than ever before. In this regard, proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) based on hydrogen and methanol are very promising technologies. By harnessing the controlled conversion of hydrogen into electrical energy, such fuel cells generate power while producing environmentally benign water as a byproduct. The proton conductivity of proton-exchange membranes (PEM) contributes to the overall efficiency of a PEMFC. Research on materials suitable for use as PEMs is, therefore, a dynamic field aiming to make PEMFC technologies a reality.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The consumption of nonrenewable fossil fuels has caused severe environmental damage. Correspondingly, the need for alternative green energy sources is more urgent than ever before. In this regard, proton-exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) based on hydrogen and methanol are very promising technologies. By harnessing the controlled conversion of hydrogen into electrical energy, such fuel cells generate power while producing environmentally benign water as a byproduct. The proton conductivity of proton-exchange membranes (PEM) contributes to the overall efficiency of a PEMFC. Research on materials suitable for use as PEMs is, therefore, a dynamic field aiming to make PEMFC technologies a reality.

elements.content: Materials being used as PEMs must exhibit a high proton conductivity at the working conditions of the targeted PEMFC. To date, Nafion and Nafion-like polymers with acidic functionality are widely used as membrane materials due to their high proton conductivity in the range of 10–1 to 10–2 S cm–1 at a higher relative humidity (RH). However, these materials suffer from high costs, a hazardous production process, and a poor performance at high temperatures, limiting their versatility. For further developments of PEMFC, a broader range of materials is needed to extend the scope of their applications.
elements.clean_text: Materials being used as PEMs must exhibit a high proton conductivity at the working conditions of the targeted PEMFC. However, these materials suffer from high costs, a hazardous production process, and a poor performance at high temperatures, limiting their versatility. For further developments of PEMFC, a broader range of materials is needed to extend the scope of their applications.

elements.content: Recent efforts have identified crystalline porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as a promising class of materials for use as PEMs due to their diverse and tunable framework structures, high porosity, and physicochemical properties. Furthermore, the high crystallinity of MOFs offers an excellent opportunity to understand the proton-conducting mechanism by investigating the proton transfer pathway and the structure–property relationships by using diffraction techniques and theoretical calculation. Two main approaches exist for improving the performance of MOF-based proton-conductive electrolytes. The first approach is based on including proton carrier guest molecules (ammonium-based cations, N-heterocycle-based molecules) into the MOF pores. In the second approach, organic linkers with acidic functionalities (sulfono- or phosphono-groups) are included in the MOF structure. In this regard, phosphonate-based MOFs are gaining interest for designing potential proton conductors. Aryl phosphonic acid linkers provide extremely rich and robust metal-binding modes, resulting in a great variety of possible structures with unique thermal and chemical stability. Moreover, the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of phosphonic acid participate in the formation of hydrogen bond networks with the lattice water (solvent) molecules, which facilitates the proton conduction.

elements.content: Conventionally, MOFs are prepared under hydro- or solvothermal conditions, which require a large volume of solvents and long reaction times. These methods also suffer from a poor scalability. Mechanochemical synthesis (i.e., co-grinding solid reagents dry or with a negligible amount of liquid) is an attractive alternative to conventional solution-based synthesis. This environmentally benign technique has been extensively applied for the rapid and high-yielding synthesis of a wide range of molecules and materials including cocrystal, organometallic complexes, and composites. Recently, mechanochemical syntheses have been used for the preparation of porous MOFs for different functional applications, while its applications toward the synthesis of proton-conducting MOFs is scarce.

elements.content: Here, we report the mechanochemical synthesis of three novel MOFs of Co­(II), Fe­(II), and Cu­(II) based on 1,4-phenylenediphosphonic acid with bipyridine-based auxiliary linkers. Structure analysis revealed that all the frameworks consist of a defined hydrogen-bonded network formed between phosphonate and guest water molecules. These MOFs exhibit a significant vapor sorption. These structural features represent the conventional criteria for proton conductivity in framework materials. All three MOFs displayed a high proton conductivity under elevated humidity and over a wide temperature range. Furthermore, a detailed investigation of the proton-conducting mechanism has been presented.

Furthermore, a detailed investigation of the proton-conducting mechanism has been presented.

elements.content: Block-shaped crystals of {Co­(H2PhDPA)­(4,4′-bipy)­(H2O)·2H2O} n (BAM-1), {Fe­(H2PhDPA)­(4,4′-bipy)­(H2O)·2H2O} n (BAM-2), and {Cu­(H2PhDPA)­(dpe)2(H2O)2·2H2O} (BAM-3) were obtained at room temperature by slow diffusion of aqueous solutions of disodium salt of 1,4-phenylenediphosphonic acid (Na2H2PhDPA) and methanolic solution of 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy) or 1,2-di­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (dpe) with corresponding metal­(II) solution [Co­(II), Fe­(II), and Cu­(II)]. Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that BAM-1 and BAM-2 are isostructural, differing only in the metal species [Co­(II) or Fe­(II)]. The structures of both BAM-1 and BAM-2 are described using BAM-1 as an example, . BAM-1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21, and the asymmetric unit contains one Co­(II) cation, one H2PhDPA dianion, one 4,4′-bipy molecule, one coordinated water molecule, and two molecules of lattice water. Here, each Co­(II) cation is coordinated in a slightly distorted octahedron by two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2 c ) from two different bridging 4,4′-bipy molecules, three oxygen atoms (O1, O2 a , and O5 b ) from three different H2PhDPA dianions, and one water molecule (O7) (a). The selected bond lengths and bond angles are reported in Table S2. In each H2PhDPA dianion, one phosphono group binds to a Co­(II) cation in a monodentate binding mode and the second phosphono group binds two Co­(II) cations in a bridging bidentate fashion, resulting in the formation of sheets in the crystallographic bc plane (b). The sheets are pillared by 4,4′-bipy linkers into a three-dimensional (3D) structure with one-dimensional (1D) channels along the b-axis that are filled with water molecules (c). In the 1D channels, the water molecules are hydrogen bonded with uncoordinated acidic OH groups of phosphonate moieties and the coordinated water (d). Structural analysis with TOPOS reveals that BAM-1 exhibits a (3,5)-connected binodal network with the Schläfli symbol {63}­{69.8} (e). A detailed structural description of BAM-2 is provided in the Supporting Information (Figure S1 and Table S3).

(b) View of metal phosphonate zig-zag sheets along the crystallographic bc-plane. (c) Three-dimensional network structure filled with water channels along the crystallographic b-axis. elements.content: BAM-3 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group with the Cu­(II) cation located in a special position (half-occupied) along with one monodentate pendant dpe ligand, one-half H2PhDPA dianion, one coordinated water, and one lattice water. Here, each Cu­(II) ion is coordinated in a slightly distorted octahedron by two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N1 a ) from two monodentate pendant dpe, two oxygen atoms (O1 and O1 a ) from two different H2PhDPA dianions, and two water molecules (O5 and O5 a ) (a). The selected bond lengths and bond angles are reported in Table S4. Here, each H2PhDPA dianion connects two different Cu­(II) centers via bridging in a monodentate fashion to form a 1D chain with pendent monodentate dpe ligands along the crystallographic b-axis (b). In the crystal packing, these 1D chains are connected to each other by hydrogen-bonding interactions between the nitrogen atom (N2) of the pendent dpe ligand and the phosphonate −OH group to form 3D supramolecular arrangements (c) with the 1D channels filled with lattice water molecules along the crystallographic a-axis. The supramolecular structure is also stabilized by interchain π–π interactions (4.2 Å). The lattice water molecules are also hydrogen-bonded with the phosphonate O and −OH groups in a complicated fashion (d). It is worth noting that in all three structures the lattice water molecules are hydrogen-bonded with uncoordinated acidic phosphonate −OH groups and the coordinated water to form complicated hydrogen-bonded supramolecular structures, which are the key element for proton conduction.

elements.content: A search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, version 5.43, 2021) revealed nine mixed ligand coordination polymers of diphosphonate-based ligands and 4,4′-bipy. Only one structure with dpe was known, suggesting diphosphonate-based ligands are rarely used for designing mixed-ligand frameworks. All the reported diphosphonate-based coordination polymers show either two-dimensional (2D) or 3D networks, depending on the coordination mode of the phosphonate ligands. If the phosphonate group is coordinated with the metal center in a monodentate fashion, then 2D structures result. However, when the phosphonate ligand is connected with the metal center by di- or tri-dentate fashion, 3D structures are formed. The structures of BAM-1 and BAM-2 follow the same trend, showing a 3D network structure with each H2PhDPA dianion connected with Co­(II) or Fe­(II) in a bidentate fashion. In contrast, H2PhDPA dianions are connected in a bidentate fashion in BAM-3, leading to a 1D structure due to the monodentate pendant dpe ligand.

elements.content: MOF materials are generally used in their powder state for practical applications. We, therefore, focused on the bulk synthesis of BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3 by environmentally benign mechanochemical synthesis. To reduce the environmental impact, we used water for liquid-assisted grinding (LAG). Mechanochemical grinding of Co­(OAc)2·4H2O with 4,4′-bipy and H4PhDPA for 30 min produces BAM-1. The acetate ion acts as a base, deprotonating H4-PhDPA to yield volatile acetic acid. Evaporation of the acetic acid along with water effectively pushes the equilibrium toward the products, leaving BAM-1 as the only solid phase (). The milling reaction was conducted first at a 100 mg scale. Analysis of the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern revealed an excellent agreement with the simulated PXRD pattern (obtained from single-crystal data), indicating that the reaction was successful (). The synthesis was then upscaled tenfold, and the PXRD was still in excellent agreement with the simulated pattern (). For the mechanochemical synthesis of BAM-2, FeCl2·4 H2O was reacted with 4,4′-bipy and H4PhDPA instead of Fe­(OAc)2 because of its instability under ambient atmosphere. Starting from FeCl2·4 H2O, we added two equivalents of NaHCO3 as a base to deprotonate the H4-PhDPA, forming NaCl (). After 30 min milling, the product showed reflections of BAM-2 alongside those of NaCl (Figure S2). Consecutive washing of the milled powder with water yielded pure form BAM-2 ( and S2). BAM-3 was mechanochemically synthesized by the same procedure as BAM-1 using Cu­(OAc)2·H2O instead of Co­(OAc)2·4H2O. A blue powder was obtained after 30 min of grinding (). The PXRD pattern was also in good agreement with the simulated PXRD pattern ().

For all three compounds, we observed peak broadening in the PXRD patterns (). This is a typical characteristic for mechanochemically synthesized materials due to the formation of nanostructures and defects. The SEM images of all three mechanochemically ground powders exhibit differently sized and shaped particles, albeit all within the nanoscale domain (Figures S6–S8). We note that we performed all subsequent characterization of these compounds using the mechanochemically synthesized powders, thereby reflecting the performance of the “scalable” product material.

elements.content: To study the thermal stability of all three MOFs, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on the mechanochemically prepared powders in a temperature range of 25–1000 °C under a N2 atmosphere at a 10 °C/min heating rate. At room temperature, upon drying, the crystal of BAM-1 and BAM-2 become visibly opaque, suggesting the removal of lattice water from the crystal lattice. The TGA curve of BAM-1 shows an initial weight loss of 3.63% at 95 °C. This weight loss is consistent with the removal of the one coordinated water molecule (calc. mass 3.56%) (). The dehydrated framework of BAM-1 was stable at 150 °C. Variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) also showed the emergence of new reflections in powders of mechanochemically prepared BAM-1 at ∼50 °C (Figure S6). This can be ascribed to the phase transformation due to the loss of all lattice water molecules. Heating above ca. 50 °C led to a significant reduction of BAM-1 crystallinity until the sample transformed into an unidentified noncrystalline product upon the loss of the coordinated water molecule at 200 °C. Similarly, BAM-2 shows an initial weight loss of 3.73% at 105 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (calc. mass 3.59%) (). Subsequent weight loss takes place upon further heating, followed by decomposition to an unidentified product. VT-PXRD studies also showed that BAM-2 retains a high degree of crystallinity until 130 °C, and then a decrease in the intensity with the disappearance of some peaks of the PXRD patterns were observed, signifying the decomposition of the framework at high temperature (∼190 °C) (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: To study the thermal stability of all three MOFs, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on the mechanochemically prepared powders in a temperature range of 25-1000 °C under a N2 atmosphere at a 10 °C/min heating rate. At room temperature, upon drying, the crystal of BAM-1 and BAM-2 become visibly opaque, suggesting the removal of lattice water from the crystal lattice. The TGA curve of BAM-1 shows an initial weight loss of 3.63% at 95 °C. This weight loss is consistent with the removal of the one coordinated water molecule (calc. mass 3.56%) (). The dehydrated framework of BAM-1 was stable at 150 °C. Variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) also showed the emergence of new reflections in powders of mechanochemically prepared BAM-1 at ~50 °C (Figure S6). This can be ascribed to the phase transformation due to the loss of all lattice water molecules. Heating above ca. 50 °C led to a significant reduction of BAM-1 crystallinity until the sample transformed into an unidentified noncrystalline product upon the loss of the coordinated water molecule at 200 °C. Similarly, BAM-2 shows an initial weight loss of 3.73% at 105 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (calc. mass 3.59%) (). Subsequent weight loss takes place upon further heating, followed by decomposition to an unidentified product. VT-PXRD studies also showed that BAM-2 retains a high degree of crystallinity until 130 °C, and then a decrease in the intensity with the disappearance of some peaks of the PXRD patterns were observed, signifying the decomposition of the framework at high temperature (~190 °C) (Figure S7).

elements.content: BAM-3 exhibited an interesting stepwise thermal profile. Weight loss was first observed at 90 °C, and the framework lost 9.88% mass by 140 °C. This corresponds to the loss of two guest and two coordinated water molecules (calc. mass 9.78%). The dehydrated framework then remained stable up to 190 °C (). The VT-PXRD studies showed that many new reflections appeared in the PXRD pattern beginning at 90 °C, with a complete structural phase transition observed by 100 °C, presumably owing to the removal of guest and coordinated water molecules from the framework (Figure S8). At 180 °C, VT-PXRD showed that another crystalline phase transition began and ended at 200 °C. The structure of both high-temperature phases could not be solved from the laboratory powder diffraction data but will be the subject of follow-up investigations.

elements.content: To study the porous nature of all three frameworks, N2 sorption studies at 77 K were carried out on partially dehydrated frameworks. Owing to the decomposition of the frameworks, as evident from thermal and VT-PXRD studies, the complete dehydration of all these compounds is not possible. The N2 isotherms of powdered BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3 show type II profiles with the final uptakes of 45, 111, and 59 cm3 g–1, respectively (Figure S9). These values suggest only surface adsorption occurs. The BET surface areas were determined and showed relatively low values of 14.04 m2 g–1, 26.17 m2 g–1, and 12.14 m2 g–1 for BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3, respectively (Figure S9). Furthermore, to check the water affinity of all three frameworks, dynamic vapor sorption (DVS) using water was carried out at room temperature (). BAM-1 showed an uptake of ∼45 cm3 g–1 at low pressure (P/P 0 ≈ 0.025), which suggests very high-water affinity of the framework. After that, the H2O adsorption profile of BAM-1 displayed a gate opening type profile atP/P 0 ≈ 0.25, suggesting the flexible nature of the framework. The final uptake reached 163 cm3 g–1, corresponding to the sorption of 3.3 molecules of H2O per formula unit. Despite the isostructural features of BAM-1 and BAM-2, the water adsorption profile of latter is remarkably different than the former. BAM-2 also exhibited high affinity towards water at very low pressure and adsorbed ∼62 cm3 g–1 at P/P 0 ≈ 0.05. After that, a gradual uptake was observed with an increasing pressure. It reaches a maximum uptake of 163 mL g–1, which also corresponds to 3.3 water molecules per formula unit. For BAM-3, the water adsorption isotherm exhibited marked gate-opening at P/P 0 = 0.15. This effect is ascribed to the flexible nature of the BAM-3 framework for a strong interaction of water molecules towards the unsaturated metal sites of activated BAM-3 (). The final uptake of BAM-3 reached 150 cm3 g–1, which correspond to 4.5 molecules of H2O per formula unit. The desorption curves of all three compound did not follow the adsorption pathway and exhibited large hysteresis with kinetic trapping of water molecules due to the small pore windows in the frameworks.

elements.content: The presence of well-defined hydrogen bonded water channels, the good thermal stability and the strong water affinity of BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3 prompted us to study their proton conductivity. Measurements were performed by alternating current impedance spectroscopy, using pelletized powder samples over a large range of temperatures (25–90 °C) and RH levels (68–98%), as shown in and S10–S12. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) results were represented in a Nyquist form, where Z′′ (imaginary component of the impedance) is plotted as the function of Z′ (real component of impedance). All the Nyquist plots showed a semicircle in the high-frequency region followed by an elongated tail in the low-frequency region. The Nyquist plots were fitted to a suitable equivalent circuit ((R1/Q1) + (R2/Q2) + Q3), where R1 and R2 represent resistance and Q1, Q2, and Q3 represent constant-phase elements, as shown in the inset of a. On fitting, the Nyquist plots each resolved into a well-fitted high-frequency semicircle with a lower radius and a low-frequency semicircle with a high radius, representing the resistance of the material analogous to the proton conductivity and the contact resistance, respectively. The conductivities were calculated from the fitted high-frequency semicircle of the Nyquist plots and were found to be highly dependent on the RH (Figures S10–S12). The strongly hydrogen-bonded guest water molecules are poorly labile at low humidity. However, their mobility increases with RH, resulting in an enhanced proton conductivity performance. For instance, all the frameworks reported here showed a very poor proton conductivity at 25 °C and low RH. When the RH was increased, keeping the temperature constant, the conductivity of BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3 increased 2-fold, reaching 2.1 × 10–6, 3.4 × 10–6, and 5.1 × 10–6 S cm–1, respectively, at 98% RH (Figures S10–S12). Moreover, when the temperature was gradually increased (at a constant RH of 98%), the conductivities of BAM-1 and BAM-2 also increased. This is a typical proton conductivity behavior. At 90 °C and 98% RH, the conductivity of BAM-1 and BAM-2 reached maximum values of 4.9 × 10–5 (a) and 4.4 × 10–5 S cm–1 (b), respectively. For BAM-3, increasing the temperature also led to an increase in the conductivity, reaching a maximum value of 1.4 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 50 °C and 98% RH (c). The proton conductivity remains almost constant with a further increase in temperature but suddenly drops at 90 °C to 7.6 × 10–6 S cm–1. This is consistent with the phase transition observed by VT-PXRD in which lattice water, and hence the hydrogen bonding network is lost (Figure S8). Following conductivity measurements, PXRD patterns indicate no irreversible structural transition in any of the reported compounds (Figure S13). The proton conductivities of BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3 are comparable to the recently reported mixed-ligand phosphonate MOFs.

elements.content: The activation energy (E a) is the key parameter to understand the proton transport mechanism. For example, proton conduction in materials with E a less than 0.4 eV proceeds by transferring protons between the H-donor and acceptor, that is, the Grotthuss mechanism. In contrast, for material with E a greater than 0.4 eV, proton conduction proceeds through the vehicle mechanism wherein protons transfer via the diffusion of protonated carriers. At 98% RH, the values of E a extracted from the Arrhenius plots were 0.37 eV for BAM-1, 0.23 eV for BAM-2, and 0.10 eV for BAM-3, respectively (d). These values suggest that proton conduction proceeds by the Grotthuss mechanism in all three compounds. This is presumably facilitated by the well-defined hydrogen bonding between guest waters with uncoordinated OH groups of the phosphonates and coordinated water molecules.

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized three novel proton-conductive MOFs, {Co­(H2PhDPA)­(4,4′-bipy)­(H2O)·2H2O} n (BAM-1), {Fe­(H2PhDPA)­(4,4′-bipy)­(H2O)·2H2O} n (BAM-2), and {Cu­(H2PhDPA)­(dpe)2(H2O)2·2H2O} n (BAM-3) at gram scale by environmentally benign mechanochemical methods using a minimum amount of water. In all the framework structures, extended hydrogen-bonding interactions were identified between uncoordinated acidic phosphonate −OH groups and coordinated water molecules in the 1D channels. This hydrogen bonding could facilitate the proton hopping mechanism. The proton conductivities were measured to be 4.9 × 10–5 and 4.4 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 90 °C and 98% RH for the 3D isostructural BAM-1 and BAM-2, respectively. In contrast, BAM-3 was found to have its highest proton conductivity of 1.4 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 50 °C and 98% RH. Attempts to measure BAM-3 conductivity at higher temperatures led to dehydration of the material, followed by a crystalline phase transition, detrimental to the material proton conductivity. The present work highlights the fact that green mechanochemical synthesis can be used as an alternative method to conventional solvent-assisted synthesis of proton-conductive MOFs with appropriate organic linkers for the generation of green energy.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have synthesized three novel proton-conductive MOFs, {Co(H2PhDPA)(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)⋅2H2O} n  (BAM-1), {Fe(H2PhDPA)(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)⋅2H2O} n  (BAM-2), and {Cu(H2PhDPA)(dpe)2(H2O)2⋅2H2O} n  (BAM-3) at gram scale by environmentally benign mechanochemical methods using a minimum amount of water. In all the framework structures, extended hydrogen-bonding interactions were identified between uncoordinated acidic phosphonate -OH groups and coordinated water molecules in the 1D channels. This hydrogen bonding could facilitate the proton hopping mechanism. The proton conductivities were measured to be 4.9 × 10-5 and 4.4 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 90 °C and 98% RH for the 3D isostructural BAM-1 and BAM-2, respectively. In contrast, BAM-3 was found to have its highest proton conductivity of 1.4 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 50 °C and 98% RH. Attempts to measure BAM-3 conductivity at higher temperatures led to dehydration of the material, followed by a crystalline phase transition, detrimental to the material proton conductivity. The present work highlights the fact that green mechanochemical synthesis can be used as an alternative method to conventional solvent-assisted synthesis of proton-conductive MOFs with appropriate organic linkers for the generation of green energy.

elements.content: An aqueous solution (10 mL) of the disodium salt of 1,4-phenylenediphosphonic acid (Na2H2PhDPA; 1 mmol, 282.04 mg) was added to a methanolic solution (10 mL) of 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy; 1 mmol, 156.19 mg) and stirred for 30 min to ensure even mixing. In a separate beaker, an aqueous solution (10 mL) of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 291.03 mg) was prepared. Hereafter, 6 mL of the above-mixed linker solution was slowly and carefully layered over 3 mL of the metal salt solution. Pink needle-shaped crystals were obtained from the interface of the two layers after 1 week. After extraction, the crystals were washed with methanol and air-dried.

elements.content: In a typical grinding experiment, Co­(OAc)2·4H2O (0.155 mmol, 38.7 mg), H4-PhDPA (0.155 mmol, 37.0 mg), and 4,4′-bipy (0.155 mmol, 24.3 mg) were placed into an acrylic milling jar with polyoxymethylene caps (4 mL of approximate volume) alongside one stainless-steel milling ball (7 mm diameter). After adding 20 μL of Milli-Q water, the closed milling jar was placed into a Pulverisette 23 vertical ball mill (Fritsch GmbH, Germany). The mixture was ground at a frequency of 50 Hz for 30 min, and the obtained damp, pink powder was washed three times with water and air-dried subsequently.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanochemical Synthesis by LAG

BAM-1

In a typical grinding experiment, Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (0.155 mmol, 38.7 mg), H4-PhDPA (0.155 mmol, 37.0 mg), and 4,4'-bipy (0.155 mmol, 24.3 mg) were placed into an acrylic milling jar with polyoxymethylene caps (4 mL of approximate volume) alongside one stainless-steel milling ball (7 mm diameter). After adding 20 μL of Milli-Q water, the closed milling jar was placed into a Pulverisette 23 vertical ball mill (Fritsch GmbH, Germany). The mixture was ground at a frequency of 50 Hz for 30 min, and the obtained damp, pink powder was washed three times with water and air-dried subsequently.

An aqueous solution (10 mL) of the disodium salt of 1,4-phenylenediphosphonic acid (Na2H2PhDPA; 1 mmol, 282.04 mg) was added to a methanolic solution (10 mL) of 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy; 1 mmol, 156.19 mg) and stirred for 30 min to ensure even mixing. In a separate beaker, an aqueous solution (10 mL) of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1 mmol, 291.03 mg) was prepared. Hereafter, 6 mL of the above-mixed linker solution was slowly and carefully layered over 3 mL of the metal salt solution. Pink needle-shaped crystals were obtained from the interface of the two layers after 1 week. After extraction, the crystals were washed with methanol and air-dried.

{Fe(H2PhDPA)(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)⋅2H2O} n  (BAM-2)

The synthesis of compound BAM-2 is similar to compound 1, except for the metal salt, which was changed to FeCl2⋅4H2O (1 mmol, 198.81 mmol). Dark brown needle-shaped crystals were obtained at the junction of both solutions after 1 week.

Mechanochemical Synthesis by LAG

BAM-1

In a typical grinding experiment, Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (0.155 mmol, 38.7 mg), H4-PhDPA (0.155 mmol, 37.0 mg), and 4,4'-bipy (0.155 mmol, 24.3 mg) were placed into an acrylic milling jar with polyoxymethylene caps (4 mL of approximate volume) alongside one stainless-steel milling ball (7 mm diameter). After adding 20 μL of Milli-Q water, the closed milling jar was placed into a Pulverisette 23 vertical ball mill (Fritsch GmbH, Germany). The mixture was ground at a frequency of 50 Hz for 30 min, and the obtained damp, pink powder was washed three times with water and air-dried subsequently.

cln_elements.content:
To study the thermal stability of all three MOFs, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on the mechanochemically prepared powders in a temperature range of 25–1000 °C under a N2 atmosphere at a 10 °C/min heating rate. At room temperature, upon drying, the crystal of BAM-1 and BAM-2 become visibly opaque, suggesting the removal of lattice water from the crystal lattice. The TGA curve of BAM-1 shows an initial weight loss of 3.63% at 95 °C. This weight loss is consistent with the removal of the one coordinated water molecule (calc. mass 3.56%) (). The dehydrated framework of BAM-1 was stable at 150 °C. Variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) also showed the emergence of new reflections in powders of mechanochemically prepared BAM-1 at ∼50 °C (Figure S6). This can be ascribed to the phase transformation due to the loss of all lattice water molecules. Heating above ca. 50 °C led to a significant reduction of BAM-1 crystallinity until the sample transformed into an unidentified noncrystalline product upon the loss of the coordinated water molecule at 200 °C. Similarly, BAM-2 shows an initial weight loss of 3.73% at 105 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (calc. mass 3.59%) (). Subsequent weight loss takes place upon further heating, followed by decomposition to an unidentified product. VT-PXRD studies also showed that BAM-2 retains a high degree of crystallinity until 130 °C, and then a decrease in the intensity with the disappearance of some peaks of the PXRD patterns were observed, signifying the decomposition of the framework at high temperature (∼190 °C) (Figure S7).

BAM-3 exhibited an interesting stepwise thermal profile. Weight loss was first observed at 90 °C, and the framework lost 9.88% mass by 140 °C. This corresponds to the loss of two guest and two coordinated water molecules (calc. mass 9.78%). The dehydrated framework then remained stable up to 190 °C (). The VT-PXRD studies showed that many new reflections appeared in the PXRD pattern beginning at 90 °C, with a complete structural phase transition observed by 100 °C, presumably owing to the removal of guest and coordinated water molecules from the framework (Figure S8). At 180 °C, VT-PXRD showed that another crystalline phase transition began and ended at 200 °C. The structure of both high-temperature phases could not be solved from the laboratory powder diffraction data but will be the subject of follow-up investigations.

To study the porous nature of all three frameworks, N2 sorption studies at 77 K were carried out on partially dehydrated frameworks. Owing to the decomposition of the frameworks, as evident from thermal and VT-PXRD studies, the complete dehydration of all these compounds is not possible. The N2 isotherms of powdered BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3 show type II profiles with the final uptakes of 45, 111, and 59 cm3 g–1, respectively (Figure S9). These values suggest only surface adsorption occurs. The BET surface areas were determined and showed relatively low values of 14.04 m2 g–1, 26.17 m2 g–1, and 12.14 m2 g–1 for BAM-1, BAM-2, and BAM-3, respectively (Figure S9). Furthermore, to check the water affinity of all three frameworks, dynamic vapor sorption (DVS) using water was carried out at room temperature (). BAM-1 showed an uptake of ∼45 cm3 g–1 at low pressure (P/P 0 ≈ 0.025), which suggests very high-water affinity of the framework. After that, the H2O adsorption profile of BAM-1 displayed a gate opening type profile atP/P 0 ≈ 0.25, suggesting the flexible nature of the framework. The final uptake reached 163 cm3 g–1, corresponding to the sorption of 3.3 molecules of H2O per formula unit. Despite the isostructural features of BAM-1 and BAM-2, the water adsorption profile of latter is remarkably different than the former. BAM-2 also exhibited high affinity towards water at very low pressure and adsorbed ∼62 cm3 g–1 at P/P 0 ≈ 0.05. After that, a gradual uptake was observed with an increasing pressure. It reaches a maximum uptake of 163 mL g–1, which also corresponds to 3.3 water molecules per formula unit. For BAM-3, the water adsorption isotherm exhibited marked gate-opening at P/P 0 = 0.15. This effect is ascribed to the flexible nature of the BAM-3 framework for a strong interaction of water molecules towards the unsaturated metal sites of activated BAM-3 (). The final uptake of BAM-3 reached 150 cm3 g–1, which correspond to 4.5 molecules of H2O per formula unit. The desorption curves of all three compound did not follow the adsorption pathway and exhibited large hysteresis with kinetic trapping of water molecules due to the small pore windows in the frameworks.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of BAM-1. (a) Coordination environment around the octahedrally coordinated Co­(II) center; here, Co (purple), O (red), N (blue), P (orange), and C (black). (b) View of metal phosphonate zig-zag sheets along the crystallographic bc-plane. (c) Three-dimensional network structure filled with water channels along the crystallographic b-axis. (d) View of well-defined hydrogen-bonding interaction (green dotted lines) between lattice water, the uncoordinated acidic phosphonate −OH group, and the coordinated water molecules. (e) Simplified (3,5)-connected binodal network net of BAM-1. Framework hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

(b) View of the extended 1D chain connected by bridging monodentate H2PhDPA and a pendent monodentate dpe ligand with Cu­(II) along the crystallographic b-axis. (c) Supramolecular 3D network constructed by hydrogen bonding interactions. (d) View of well-defined hydrogen-bonding interaction (green dotted lines) between lattice water, uncoordinated acidic OH of the phosphonate group, and the coordinated water molecules.
